questions.question_text: Which two are true for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure DNS? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: B and C are correct options!
B and C are legit

choices.D: It does not provide DDoS protection.
choices.A: It can function only as a primary DNS.
choices.B: It supports other cloud providers such as AWS and Azure.
choices.C: It supports segregation of traffic by using the private pool.

discussion.content:
Correct is B

choices.B: Objects are automatically encrypted as they are uploaded to object storage and decrypted upon retrieval
choices.C: You must manually decrypt the data when retrieving from OCI object storage
choices.A: You must manually enable server-side encryption for each object as you upload to OCI object storage
choices.D: Only the object data is encrypted and the user-defined metadata that is associated with the object is not encrypted

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) object storage support for server-side encryption?

You deployed a compute instance (VM.Standard2.16) to run a SQL database. After a few weeks, you need to increase disk performance by using NVMe disks; the number of CPUs will not change. As a first step you terminate the instance and preserve the boot volume.
What is the next step?

choices.B: Create a new instance using a VM.DenseIO2.8 shape using the preserved boot volume and move the SQL Database data to NVMe disks
choices.C: Create a new instance using a VM.Standard1.16 shape using the preserved boot volume and move the SQL Database data to NVMe disks
choices.D: Create a new instance using a VM.DenseIO2.16 shape using the preserved boot volume and move the SQL Database data to NVMe disks
choices.A: Create a new instance using a VM.DenseIO2.16 shape using the preserved boot volume and move the SQL Database data to block volume

discussion.content: Agree, answer is D
answer - d

comments.content: Sorry, D is correct. As the standard shapes have only block storage and not NVME storage.

discussion.content: Answer should be C. As the question says that the number of CPUs should not be changed.

Trick question, block volume is NVMe based.
"The Block Volume service uses NVMe-based storage infrastructure, and is designed for consistency. " Oracle only limits the IOPS per GB.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Concepts/blockvolumeperformance.htm

comments.content: In term of disk performance, local NVMe performance is better than block volume.

discussion.content: The question says "by using NVMe disks" so answer is D .
Answer is D: https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/References/computeshapes.htm
please explain as everywhere answer is mentioned as A

comments.content: you need a dense shape which have NVMe disks .. you choose the corresponding shape .16 but dense instead of standard .. you move your DB to NVMe to get benefit of its speed

discussion.content: B and D for sure

choices.A: Data guard implementation requires two DB Systems, one running the primary database on a virtual machine and the standby database running on bare metal
choices.B: Data guard configuration on the OCI is limited to one standby database per primary database
choices.C: Data guard configuration on the OCI is limited to a virtual machine only
choices.D: Data guard implementation requires two DB Systems, one containing the primary database and one containing the standby database

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about data guard service on DB Systems in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI)? (Choose two.)
Which two statements about fault domains are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: A & B as long as i dance
A, B. Foundation course.
A&B https://k21academy.com/oracle-compute-cloud-services-iaas/oracle-cloud-infrastructure-availability-domains-fault-domains/

choices.B: Each availability domain contains three fault domains
choices.D: A fault domain is selected automatically based on usage data
choices.C: A failed instance in a fault domain is automatically relaunched
choices.A: A fault domain is a grouping of hardware and infrastructure within an availability domain
